unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Test Statistic
question_text: A test statistic for the z- or t-distribution represents

choices.text: The probability of getting a result, or more extreme, given the null hypothesis was true.
The probability of a result, or more extreme, given the alternative hypothesis was true.
The number of standard deviations the result was away from the mean.
The distance away from the mean, using the units represented in the problem.
The amount of evidence one has to reject the alternative hypothesis.

solution:
Choices 'A' and 'B' are incorrect; these attempt to give the definition of P-value, and the latter incorrectly interprets the P-value as well.

Choice 'C' is correct; this accurately gives the definition of test statistic.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; the test statistic refers to the number of standard deviations away, not the distance.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; while a large test statistic can be thought of as sufficient evidence, it counts only potentially as evidence to reject the null hypothesis, not the alternative hypothesis.
